question: The application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure you:
options: Are applying to the brakes.
Have in a modulating control valve.
Have in the air tanks.
correct_answer: Are applying to the brakes.
why: The application pressure gauge indicates how much pressure is being applied to the brakes by the driver.

question: The spring brakes used on the chambers in a straight truck will bring you to a stop when air pressure drops below __ psi.
why: Spring brakes engage when air pressure drops below 60 psi to help stop the vehicle.

question: Parking or emergency brakes of trucks and buses can be legally held on by ___ pressure.
options: Spring
Fluid
Air
correct_answer: Spring
why: Spring brakes use spring pressure rather than air pressure to engage and hold the brakes.

question: The air compressor governor controls:
options: The speed of the air compressor.
Air pressure applied to the brakes.
When air is pumped into the air tanks.
correct_answer: When air is pumped into the air tanks.
why: The air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air tanks to maintain proper pressure.

question: Modern air brakes combine three different systems. They are the service, the parking, and the ____ brakes.
options: Drum
Foot
Emergency
correct_answer: Emergency
why: Air brake systems include service brakes (used for normal braking), parking brakes (used when parked), and emergency brakes (used when there is a failure).

question: If you do not have automatic tank drains, how often should you drain the oil and water from the bottom of compressed air storage tanks?
options: After every four hours of service.
Once a week.
At the end of each day of driving.
correct_answer: At the end of each day of driving.
why: Draining the air tanks daily prevents the buildup of water and oil, which can damage the system.

question: The proper use of the brakes when going down a long steep grade after selecting a proper gear is to brake until your speed is about ___ below the posted speed and release your brake.
options: 10 mph
5 mph
15 mph
correct_answer: 5 mph
why: Braking to 5 mph below the safe speed and then releasing the brakes allows the brakes to cool and helps prevent overheating.

question: In ideal conditions, a truck or bus with air brakes going at 55 mph would require the stopping distance of how many feet?
options: Less than 100 feet
From 100 to 300 feet.
More than 300 feet.
correct_answer: More than 300 feet.
why: A vehicle with air brakes at 55 mph in ideal conditions requires more than 300 feet to stop due to reaction time, brake lag, and braking distance.

question: If your truck or bus has dual parking control valves, you can use pressure from a separate tank to:
options: Stay parked twice as long without using up service air pressure.
Release the spring emergency/parking brakes to move a short distance.
Balance the service brake system when you are parked.
correct_answer: Release the spring emergency/parking brakes to move a short distance.
why: The dual parking control valves allow the driver to release the spring brakes temporarily to move the vehicle a short distance.

question: When is it OK to leave your truck unattended without applying the parking brakes and chocking the wheels?
options: If you are only away for a few minutes.
Never.
If you are conducting a pre-trip inspection.
correct_answer: Never.
why: The parking brakes should always be applied, and wheels chocked when leaving the vehicle unattended to prevent rolling.

question: The stop light switch:
options: Tells you when you need to use your emergency brakes.
Tells you when the air brake system is low on air pressure.
Turns on the brake lights when you put on the air brakes.
correct_answer: Turns on the brake lights when you put on the air brakes.
why: The stop light switch activates the brake lights when the brakes are applied, alerting other drivers that the vehicle is stopping.

question: The ____ shows how much pressure is in the air tanks.
options: Oil gauge
Air usage gauge
Supply pressure gauge
correct_answer: Supply pressure gauge
why: The supply pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is available in the air tanks.

question: To test air service brakes you should:
options: Brake firmly while slowly moving forward.
Brake slowly while slowly moving backward.
Stop the vehicle, brake in a low gear, depress the service brakes, and then gently pull against the brakes.
correct_answer: Brake firmly while slowly moving forward.
why: This test ensures that the service brakes are working correctly by applying them while moving slowly forward.

question: If you are driving down a steep downgrade and have reached your safe speed of 40 mph, you would apply the service brake until your speed dropped to ___ mph.
why: When descending a steep grade, braking to reduce speed by 5 mph below the safe speed helps control the vehicle without overheating the brakes.

question: If your truck has a dual air brake system, and one of the systems is low on pressure:
options: Either the front or rear brakes will not be fully functional.
The manual slack adjusters on S-Cam brakes are not set properly.
The brake drums will not be fully operational.
correct_answer: Either the front or rear brakes will not be fully functional.
why: A dual air brake system has two independent systems, and if one system is low on pressure, the corresponding brakes will not work properly.

question: The air compressor stops pumping air at what psi?
why: The air compressor typically stops pumping air at 125 psi to prevent over-pressurizing the system.

question: The spring brakes used on the chambers in a straight truck will bring you to a stop when air pressure drops below __ psi.
why: Spring brakes are designed to engage and bring the vehicle to a stop when the air pressure drops below 60 psi as a safety measure.

question: The driver must be able to see a low air pressure warning which comes on before pressure in the service air tanks falls below ___ psi.
why: A low air pressure warning light must come on before the pressure drops below 60 psi to give the driver enough time to respond.

question: Excessive use of the service brakes results in overheating which can lead to:
options: Proper adjustment of S-cam.
Increase contact between the brake drums and linings.
Expansion of the brake drums.
correct_answer: Expansion of the brake drums.
why: Overheating the brakes can cause the brake drums to expand, reducing braking effectiveness and possibly leading to brake failure.

question: The most common type of foundation brake found on heavy vehicles is the:
options: Disc.
S-cam drum.
Wedge drum.
correct_answer: S-cam drum.
why: S-cam drum brakes are the most commonly used foundation brakes on heavy vehicles due to their durability and effectiveness.

question: If you must make an emergency stop, you should brake so you:
options: Use the hand brake before the brake pedal.
Use the full power of the brakes to lock them.
Can keep your vehicle in a straight line.
correct_answer: Can keep your vehicle in a straight line.
why: In an emergency stop, it is crucial to brake in a way that maintains vehicle control and keeps the vehicle straight to avoid skidding.

question: Your truck or bus has a dual air brake system. If a low air pressure warning comes on for only one system, what should you do?
options: Reduce your speed and test the remaining system while underway.
Stop right away and safely park.
Reduce your speed and drive to the nearest garage for repairs.
correct_answer: Stop right away and safely park.
why: If one of the air brake systems is failing, it is critical to stop immediately and safely park the vehicle to avoid a brake system failure.

question: Some air brake systems have an alcohol evaporator. What may happen if you don't keep the proper level of alcohol?
options: Ice may form on the brake drums and wear them out.
The S-cam may not take back when you release the brake pedal.
Ice may form in the air brake valves and cause brake failure.
correct_answer: Ice may form in the air brake valves and cause brake failure.
why: If the alcohol level is not maintained, ice can form in the air brake valves during cold weather, causing brake failure.

question: If your vehicle has an alcohol evaporator, every day during cold weather you should:
options: Check the oil for alcohol content.
Change the alcohol from a bottle.
Check and fill the alcohol level.
correct_answer: Check and fill the alcohol level.
why: In cold weather, checking and maintaining the alcohol level daily prevents ice from forming in the air brake system.

question: The air loss rate for a straight truck or bus with the engine off and the brakes on should not be more than:
options: 2 psi in 45 seconds.
3 psi in one minute.
1 psi in 30 seconds.
correct_answer: 3 psi in one minute.
why: The air loss rate for a straight truck or bus should not exceed 3 psi per minute when the brakes are applied.

question: The braking power of the spring brakes:
options: Is not affected by the condition of the service brakes.
Depends on the service brakes being in adjustment.
Increases when the service brakes are hot.
correct_answer: Depends on the service brakes being in adjustment.
why: The effectiveness of the spring brakes depends on the proper adjustment of the service brakes, as they both work together.

question: The air brake lag distance at 55 mph on dry pavement adds about ____ feet.
why: Air brake systems have a lag time due to air travel in the lines, adding about 32 feet to the stopping distance at 55 mph.

question: Total stopping distance for air brakes is longer than that for hydraulic brakes due to ____ distance.
options: Reaction
Effective braking
Brake lag
correct_answer: Brake lag
why: Brake lag in air brake systems causes a delay between applying the brakes and the brakes engaging, making the total stopping distance longer.

question: It is accepted that too much heat caused by using your brakes too often can also cause:
options: Modulated control valve to wear out.
Brakes to fade or fail.
Brake linings to split up.
correct_answer: Brakes to fade or fail.
why: Excessive heat from frequent brake use can cause brake fade or failure, reducing braking effectiveness.

question: Repeatedly partially increasing and pressing the brake pedal may result in:
options: A buildup of brake air pressure.
No change of brake air pressure.
A loss of brake air pressure.
correct_answer: A loss of brake air pressure.
why: Repeatedly pressing the brake pedal partially can lead to a gradual loss of air pressure in the system.

question: The brake system that applies and releases the brakes when the driver uses the brake pedal is the ____ brake system.
options: Parking
Emergency
Service
correct_answer: Service
why: The service brake system is the primary system used by the driver to apply and release the brakes during normal driving.

question: An air brake system is fully charged at what psi?
why: The air brake system is considered fully charged when the air pressure reaches 125 psi, allowing the system to function properly.

question: Your truck or bus has a dual air brake system. If a low-pressure warning comes on for only one system, what should you do?
options: Bring your vehicle to a complete stop right away and safely park. Continue only after the system is fixed.
Reduce your speed and drive to the nearest garage for repairs.
Reduce your speed and test the remaining system while under way.
correct_answer: Bring your vehicle to a complete stop right away and safely park. Continue only after the system is fixed.
why: If a low air pressure warning comes on, it indicates a serious problem with the brake system. It is critical to stop immediately and only proceed once the system is fixed.

question: The brake pedal in an air brake system:
options: Controls the speed of the air compressor.
Is connected to slack adjusters by a series of rods and linkages.
Controls the air pressure applied to the brakes.
correct_answer: Controls the air pressure applied to the brakes.
why: The brake pedal controls the amount of air pressure applied to the brakes, which in turn applies the braking force.

question: The S-cam:
options: Forces the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum.
Controls the air flow to each of the brake chambers.
Pulls the brake shoes away from the drum and allows the wheels to roll freely.
correct_answer: Forces the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum.
why: The S-cam rotates and forces the brake shoes against the brake drum, causing the vehicle to slow or stop.

question: Under normal conditions, in order to engage the parking brakes the driver should:
options: Turn off the engine.
Be sure air brake system is fully pressurized.
Apply brakes by pulling the parking brake control knob out.
correct_answer: Apply brakes by pulling the parking brake control knob out.
why: The parking brakes are applied by pulling the parking brake control knob, which engages the spring brakes.

question: All air brake equipped vehicles have:
options: An air usage gauge.
A backup hydraulic system.
A supply pressure gauge.
correct_answer: A supply pressure gauge.
why: Air brake vehicles have a supply pressure gauge to monitor the air pressure in the system.

question: With air brake vehicles, the parking brake should be used:
options: Only during pre-trip inspections.
As little as possible.
Whenever you leave the vehicle unattended.
correct_answer: Whenever you leave the vehicle unattended.
why: The parking brake should always be applied when leaving the vehicle unattended to prevent it from rolling.

question: If the air compressor should develop a leak, what keeps the air in the tanks?
options: The emergency relay valve.
The tractor protection valve.
The one-way check valve.
correct_answer: The one-way check valve.
why: The one-way check valve prevents air from flowing back out of the tanks in case of a compressor leak.

question: Why drain water from compressed air tanks?
options: Water can freeze in cold weather and cause brake failure.
Water cools the compressor too much.
Water's low boiling point reduces braking power.
correct_answer: Water can freeze in cold weather and cause brake failure.
why: Water in the air brake system can freeze in cold weather, leading to brake failure.

question: Which of these is NOT a proper time to apply the parking brakes?
options: If the brakes are very hot (e.g. just after coming down a steep grade).
If you will be stopping for only one hour.
If you are going to test the parking brake to make sure that it holds the vehicle.
correct_answer: If the brakes are very hot (e.g. just after coming down a steep grade).
why: Applying the parking brakes when the brakes are very hot can cause damage to the brake components.

question: If the spring brakes are on, when should you push the brake pedal?
options: Never.
Only when driving downhill.
Only on a slippery road.
correct_answer: Never.
why: Pushing the brake pedal when the spring brakes are applied can damage the brake system and should never be done.

question: To check the free play of manual slack adjusters of S-cam brakes, you should park on:
options: Level ground, chock the wheels, and release the parking brakes.
Level ground and drain off air pressure before checking the adjustment.
Level ground and apply the parking brakes, then apply service brakes.
correct_answer: Level ground, chock the wheels, and release the parking brakes.
why: To check slack adjuster free play, the vehicle should be on level ground with wheels chocked and parking brakes released.

question: Excessive heat caused by using your brakes too often can also cause:
options: Modulated control valve to wear out.
Brakes to fade or fail.
Brake linings to split up.
correct_answer: Brakes to fade or fail.
why: Excessive heat reduces braking efficiency and can cause brake fade or failure.

question: The safety valve is set automatically when pressure is:
why: The safety valve typically releases excess air pressure at around 150 psi to protect the system.

question: If you must make an emergency stop, you should brake so you:
options: Can steer hard while braking hard.
Use the hand brake first.
Can steer and keep your vehicle in a straight line.
correct_answer: Can steer and keep your vehicle in a straight line.
why: Maintaining control of the vehicle and keeping it in a straight line is critical during an emergency stop.

question: The use of brakes on a long and steep downgrade under normal conditions is only a supplement to:
options: Use of spring brakes.
The braking effect of the engine.
The use of the front brakes limiting valve.
correct_answer: The braking effect of the engine.
why: Engine braking is the primary method for controlling speed on long, steep downgrades, with service brakes used as a supplement.

question: The most important thing to do when a low air pressure warning comes on is:
options: Up-shift.
Downshift.
Stop and safely park as soon as possible.
correct_answer: Stop and safely park as soon as possible.
why: Low air pressure is a critical warning, and the vehicle should be stopped and parked as soon as it is safe to do so.

question: The parking or emergency brake on a heavy vehicle can only be held in position by something that cannot leak away, like:
options: Hydraulic pressure.
Spring pressure.
Air pressure.
correct_answer: Spring pressure.
why: Spring brakes are held by spring pressure, which cannot leak away like air or hydraulic pressure.

question: Air braking takes more time than hydraulic braking because:
options: Air brakes use different brake drums.
Air brakes require heavier return springs.
Air brakes take more time to flow through the lines than hydraulic fluid.
correct_answer: Air brakes take more time to flow through the lines than hydraulic fluid.
why: Air braking systems have a lag time due to the time it takes for air to flow through the brake lines.
